#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Think Differently
#Text=Thinking differently is more than just a mind setup .

#Text=It means approaching problems in new , innovative ways.conceptualizing problems differently and understanding your position in relation to any particular situation in a way you ’d never thought of before .
#Text=Here are some steps to find out how we can achieve this .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Study another industry .
#Text=Go to the library and pick up a trade magazine in an industry other than your own , or grab a few books from the library , and learn about how things are done in other industries .
#Text=You might find that many of the problems people in other industries face are similar to the problems on your own , but that they ’ve developed really quite different ways of dealing with them .
#Text=Or you might well find new linkages between your own industry and the new one , linkages that might well be the basis of innovative partnerships in the future .
#Text=Learn about another religion .
#Text=Religions are the way that humans organize and understand their relationships not only with the supernatural or divine but with each other .
#Text=Learning about how such relations are structured can teach you a lot about how people relate to each other and the world around them .

#Text=Starting to see the reason in another religion can also help you develop mental flexibility – when you really look at all the different ways people comprehend the same mysteries , and the fact that they generally manage to survive regardless of what they believe , you start to see the limitations of whatever dogma or doxy you follow , a revelation that will transfer quite a bit into the non-religious parts of your life .
#Text=Take a class .

#Text=Learning a new topic will not only teach you a new set of facts and figures , it will teach you a new way of looking at and making sense of aspects of your everyday life or of the society or natural world you live in .
#Text=This in turn will help expand both how you look at problems and the breadth of possible solutions you can come up with .
#Text=Read a novel in an unfamiliar genre .
#Text=Reading is one of the great mental stimulators in our society , but it ’s easy to get into a rut .

#Text=Try reading something you ’d never have touched otherwise – if you read literary fiction , try a mystery or science fiction novel ; if you read a lot of hard-boiled detective novels , try a romance ; and so on .
#Text=Pay attention not only to the story but to the particular problems the author has to deal with .
#Text=For instance , how does the fantasy author bypass your normal skepticism about magic and pull you into their story ?
#Text=Try to connect those problems to problems you face in your own field .
#Text=For example , how might your marketing team overcome your audiences normal reticence about a new “ miracle ” product ?
#Text=Write a poem .
#Text=While most problem-solving leans heavily on our brain ’s logical centers , poetry neatly bridges our more rational left-brain though processes and our more creative right-brain processes .
#Text=Though it may feel foolish ( and getting comfortable with feeling foolish might be another way to think outside the box ) , try writing a poem about the problem you ’re working on .

#Text=Your poem does n’t necessarily have to propose a solution – the idea is to shift your thinking away from your brain ’s logic centers and into a more creative part of the brain , where it can be mulled over in a non-rational way .
#Text=Remember , nobody has to ever see your poem …
#Text=Draw a picture .
#Text=Drawing a picture is even more right-brained , and can help break your logical left-brain ’s hold on a problem the same way a poem can .
#Text=Also , visualizing a problem engages other modes of thinking that we do n’t normally use , bringing you another creative boost .
#Text=Turn it upside down .
#Text=Turning something upside-down , whether physically by flipping a piece of paper around or metaphorically by re-imagining it can help you see patterns that would n’t otherwise be apparent .

#Text=The brain has a bunch of pattern-making habits that often obscure other , more subtle patterns at work ; changing the orientation of things can hide the more obvious patterns and make other patterns emerge .
#Text=For example , you might ask what a problem would look like if the least important outcome were the most important , and how you ’d then try to solve it .
#Text=Work backwards .
#Text=Just like turning a thing upside down , working backwards breaks the brain ’s normal conception of causality .
#Text=This is the key to backwards planning , for example , where you start with a goal and think back through the steps needed to reach it until you get to where you are right now .
#Text=Ask a child for advice .
#Text=Do n’t buy into the notion that children are inherently ore creative before society “ ruins ” them , but children can think and speak with an ignorance of convention that is often helpful .
#Text=Ask a child how they might tackle a problem , or if you do n’t have a child around think about how you might reformulate a problem so that a child could understand it if one was available .

#Text=Do n’t run out and build a boat made out of cookies because a child told you to , though – the idea is n’t to do what the child says , necessarily , but to jog your own thinking into a more unconventional path .
#Text=Invite randomness .
#Text=If you ’ve ever seen video of Jackson Pollock painting , you have seen a masterful painter consciously inviting randomness into his work .
#Text=Pollock exercises a great deal of control over his brushes and paddles , in the service of capturing the stray drips and splashes of paint that make up his work .

#Text=Embracing mistakes and incorporating them into your projects , developing strategies that allow for random input , working amid chaotic juxtapositions of sound and form – all of these can help to move beyond everyday patterns of thinking into the sublime .
#Text=Take a shower .
#Text=There ’s some kind of weird psychic link between showering and creativity .
#Text=Who knows why ?
#Text=Maybe it ’s because your mind is on other things , maybe it ’s because you ’re naked , maybe it ’s the warm water relaxing you – it ’s a mystery .
#Text=But a lot of people swear by it .
#Text=So maybe when the status quo response to some circumstance just is n’t working , try taking a shower and see if something remarkable does n’t occur to you !
